title: Crowdfest task 3 “Vocabulary trainer with implicit crowdsourcing”

author: Verena Lyding, European Academy of Bozen/Bolzano (EURAC)

segmentation: So as Rodrigo Rodrigo already uncovered, we were quite a big team working on the prototypical vocabulary training with implicit crowdsourcing of language resources, and many of us are already also here today, so Anisha Alex Christos.
And Federico and Uma, and also you later to colleagues from Cyprus are not here but have participated in this task.
So quick overview and I will give you some information on the background.
Like why did we propose this task, what was our motivation?
What is the task objective?
And then the task architecture and implementation.
A few words about the challenges we encountered while working on this task.
And a little outlook on the next steps.
With that we are planning to to do.

So our aim for proposing this task was to really demonstrate this implicit crowdsourcing paradigm that we always talk about, and we wanted to do it by creating a some, creating a sample implementation that really shows what the implicit crowdsourcing thing should do.
And our approach to doing this is vocabulary trainer.
For two reasons.
We thought that vocabulary exercises really well confined use case like it's a.
It's probably the most simple one and still it has lots of possibilities and options for variability in terms of exercises you can do fill the fill the gap thing.
You can do antonyms, you can.
You can do several things.
So for us, like for you and me when we talked about implicit crowdsourcing, it's really the thing that always re currently came back.
As the as the most obvious choice.

So to just retake this magic implicit crowdsourcing that I think by now we have termed it is popping up not only from our mouth, so it's the whole idea is that we want to use language resources as the starting point to create exercises and then use the exercise crowdsourcing on learners to enhance the language resources.
So it's really this two way process.
So the objective.

Task three was to create a prototype of this specific paradigm, and it's by providing an online vocabulary trainer that has exactly these characteristics that has exercises which are generated from a language resource.
And that has learners who answered the exercises and by answering contribut to extend the resources or to improve them or to enhance them in any way that we foresee.

Then when we proposed the task crystals actually before the crowd fest, he joined in and he proposed a very similar task that in the end we included he wanted to work on vocabulary of common sense, like creating common sense ontologies or improving them.
So in the end, what happened at the crotch is is that we choose exactly this use case and build the vocabulary trainer on the common Sense ontology, namely the concept net.
And the exercises that we connected to it.
What were exercises on word meanings?
So really we took.
Really a very very simple use case.
To generate exercises on link on word, meaning from concept, net, and feeding back the results to the concept net database basically.
So the concept net just to give you a short overview.
It's a network of semantic relations between nouns and also between other words such as type of is located at is part of and so on.
So to give you an example for the word tree types of tree can be cocoa tree charity Re.
Things located Editori can be a burden leave fruit snake.
So parts of Leaf could be a branch and so on.
So we have.
Many words in this concept net and we have many relations that link to other words.
That is the basically the language resource that we start from when we designed the exercise.
So for the exercise, the clear part was it is vocabulary training for the learner group.
We said OK, it's.
Better to pick basic vocabulary training so we said it would be targeted to elementary level and we restrict ourselves.
To announce.
And then the task that is presented to the user the learning task is the user is prompt to provide words in a free text field that are related to the given word in a certain way way.
So for example, the question that is posed to the user is name.
A thing that is related to X&X can be tree.
So name the thing that is related to treat could be bird.
It could believe it could be basically anything and the input is requested as free text.
That's how we set up our whole.
We how we define the task in the on the 1st morning of the crowd 1st and then we said.
What are the subtasks that we need to address with this one?
Is the exercise generation from concept net.
We wanted to have a generic way of creating the exercise.
By taking the data from concept it.
We wanted to have a user interface that pushes the exercises to the to the user and let's them interact and we wanted to have some kind of validation mechanism.
For words that are not part of consonant, that's really the crowdsourcing part where we want to include something that is not already there.
So these are the three sub task and as you can see and as we have, excess Rodriguez has explained before the protest was really about interdisciplinary work.
So in our teams we had Julieta and Anisha who presented a bit more of the like Alicia.
You litter the language learning part and an easier language learning and language learning platform and the others were more on the computational.
A conceptual site.
So the architecture in very, very generic terms is starting on the right from the language resource that generates some kind of vocabulary exercise that is sent to the user.
Then the user's answers are evaluated in an evaluation module and depending on the outcome, the language resources in some way adjusted.

So we created one part of our team, worked on the exercise generation part like taking this stuff and putting it into a database format that can be used to generate the exercise and send them to the users.
That is just the interface tool to demonstrate how it looked like.
And then on the interface side, we walked in two smaller teams.
One was working with the Bootstrap framework to create a web interface.
This is just a screenshot and the other one is the Telegram bot that is mobile chat.
Um check tool that also has an online interface.
And both of these, like the web interface, has a like a normal web interaction mode and the Telegram interface is operated on on the mobile phone and provide certain predefined buttons.
And input a free text like both things.
So for the evaluation strategy.
What we did is when the user answers one of the exercises.
So what is related to tree?
He answers birds.
What is happening in the background is these answers are first matched against the database.
If the answer is already part of concept net, let's find the user just gets a reward.
He gets a few points, you get the thumbs up and he can continue.
In case that the answer is not part.
Of the concept of our language resource of that we depart from.
This answer is collected and here we already started with actually with the challenges.
So the answer is collected.
So the first question is what do we tell the user like we can collect it.
We can store it somewhere, but what do we tell the learner and we decided to just advise the learner that.
Thanks for your answer.
It's going to being evaluated.
You will receive feedback in a few, like in a bit of time and for now you get potential points.
So that's not on the side towards the user on the sides toward the back end.
What we do is we continue collecting answers always for the same exercise and once we have met a threshold of let's say, 10 new answer candidates for the word tree and the exercise related to.
We take stock of the situation.
The answers are ordered like they are ranked and the highest ranked answer is accepted as an you correct answer.
And only in this moment all the users that had answered.
This answer before will be notified and they will receive the information well done.
Your answer is was correct.
Your potential points points turn into active points.
And then it goes on and we said we also wanted to.
We didn't only want to reward people for having provided the correct answer, but we wanted to have an additional thing to give a special award to the person that first input it.
The answer.
So the first one that has come up with this new answer does not only get points, but you also gets a reward in form of a bitch.
In the back end, at the same time, this answers is fed back to the to the database as I said.
During the Crowd fest we made a little trial run and we collected some data.
It was quite a lot of fun.
It was also a bit criticized for being very, very limited.
We just said I think two or three words.
All the horses were coming back is legal, already said, but it was quite fun and people were matching answers also quickly.
So it's not completely out of.
Out of 'em out of scope this whole exercise, let's say.
For the evaluation strategy, we actually struggled a bit and we said the first moment is to collect a bit more data and then we can see how to adjust.
So.
So for the challenges on the teacher side, major challenge was how to select.
Materially, according to the specific language learners level, like in concept net, you have concepts like tree that are very simple, but they have might have relations or sub concepts.
Concepts to very advanced words.
So that's not a trivial task to really automatically pick the ones that align to a certain level.

For the exercise generation, we notice since it's a string matching that sometimes award can be plural or the user inputs are plural, and it's not matching, although it's already known to the database or people put a comma dot or something like.
People can easily create a.
Similar forms that have to be somehow deflected.

For the evaluation we had to struggle with the open ended Ness of Answers because actually we wanted to use existing evaluation mechanisms, but they usually work on closed class answers, so this is really an open as we found, is really an open ended research question.
And for the learner side, people complained that it's very strange to get potential points and delayed feedback, because why so how?
And we were thinking.

I mean, we cannot give them immediate feedback, so how could we make it from the user experience as somehow more like still feel good response without lying to them and without him hiding anything from them?
So the next step is we want to consider solid 8.
The code finish some of the open features for example on leaderboards and so on.
And in particular we want to set up a set of exercises that are bit more advanced that so that we can collect more meaningful data.

In order to be able to evaluate and and move forward, and then we want to publish our preliminary results on this task, we have already submitted to like basic papers on the architecture and for this experiment which we think will be very interesting also to gain more insights for the moment I can just say that tomorrow we will work on it and watch out for call for participation which will eventually reach you.
Thank you.
So thank you, this looks very interesting and actually it reminds me of a similar project for French Cozmo.
Do you know it OK?
And so I have already worked with the data that were collected through a similar system with Judy Moran.

What I notice is there is an incentive for people who take part in the game to have SS buried as possible answer, and actually you are doing that because you are giving extra point where the provider word that you don't have already.
And so, like especially for synonyms, that sometimes produce a resource that have.
Synonyms that as native learner, I do not always agree with that.
It is a synonym BC.
You think it will stretch too much?
The scope because people try to always invent new words.
That's my question or comment.
Yeah, and especially here because you're working with non native learner.
They might actually provide non word that they believe are words you know from the language.
So how would you cope with that?

OK, for the first part, I think it actually has two sides in terms of serving the language learner we could just at some point stop collecting new answers and just send them the words from the existing database.
So we could also say now we have collected so many, it's likely that new stuff will rather decrease the quality of the resource.
So we stop.
So we would remove the crowd sourcing part and just offered the learner part learning part.
That's no problem for the.
For the second question, I already forgot, so like if if they provide non word if they provide non work.
Yeah actually the evaluation thing I should have put this in the challenges.
It was one criticism that we also received that people could intentionally or unintentionally create bad results because if.
Several foreign language speakers use the same guess the same word, which is not correct.
Then we would have a problem.
So how we would counter this?
I mean we haven't found a solution to this, but in a more advanced version of this prototype we should include some input on like some knowledge about the learner.
So what is this language background?
And if we see the tree currently people with the same language background.
Write literature with two T. Then we can be suspicious and do something against it.
That would probably be the way out.
Yeah, that's a good point.
I think.
Yeah, indeed, like false friends might be a problem, but you can also turn it into a string of the application if you can help to detect such problem, yeah.
Thank you, thank you.
We're going to stop here because we don't have time left.
Thanks a lot.
